> Idempotent operations ar=
e good for various reasons - for instance to avoid multiple creation of the=
 same resource in the face of network errors. But how is it actually done i=
n practice? What are your "tricks of the trade"?
> 
> Most implementations =
I have seen requires the client to create some kind of GUID and use that in=
 a PUT operation. For instance in order to create a new "person" resource:
=
> 
> PUT /person/{person-guid} HTTP/1.1
> Content-Type: ...
> 
> ... user d=
ata ...

This is only a useful option if you want to give the client contro=
l over the parts of the URI space (client determines GUID and hence chooses=
 how the URI will look).

I'd use POST for creation because it gives more c=
ontrol to the server (over its own URI space).

Regarding idempotency, you =
have two options: 

- let the client provide a unique request ID, as outlin=
ed in the first half of http://www.prescod.net/reliable_http.html
- let the=
 server provide a use-once-only POST accepting resource as described in htt=
ps://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-nottingham-http-poe/

HTH,

Jan
